project.name: soc
project.description: The Gentoo Summer of Code subproject oversees Gentoo's participation in the 2006 Google Summer of Code.

longdescription.p: For the second year running, Google is organising a Summer of Code, funding students to work on open-source projects over the summer. For more details, see the official SoC website.

This year, Gentoo is participating as a mentor organisation. As a result, we hope to see several students working on specific projects with Gentoo over the summer, and hopefully becoming more involved long-term in Gentoo development.

body.p: Students and Developers (Mentors) may signup for the program between May 1st and May 8th. Ideas from developers are also due by the same date. There also also a limited number of slots available for both Mentors as well as Students, so please to respond quickly if you are interested.
Here is a list of some of the project ideas:

tr.ti: Repoman is a tool used by gentoo developers for Quality Assurance and commits to the tree. As it is now, additional checks are hard to implement into the application. Seeking a modular rewrite preferably in python but other languages are possible

Entails writing a graphical front-end so that people who do not necessarily know GuideXML can create compliant XML. Might consist of either a web based frontend or a client application based frontend.
gentoolkit is a set of tools that can be used to query portage about information that pertains to your system and what is installed.
Perhaps get sandbox functioning on Alpha, ARM, MIPS, or PowerPC
Write a configuration file manager (etc-update replacement)
Configuration file management on Gentoo is still a pain and could use a redesign with regards to how file updates are managed.
This GLEP would entail modifying portage to allow for critical news reports. For more information please read the GLEP
Gentoo has a wondering Baselayout package that allows for all kinds of intersting networking configurations. A GUI front-end to it would be beneficial to the community.
Modify Java Packages to build with an open source JVM

Patch packages that use proprietary classes while working with upstream. Over three hundred packages would need to be modified. This would allow platforms that are not necessarily supported by a proprietary JVM to run Java applications such as Eclipse and Azureus.
Would possibly include adding Avahi support, Dialup/Modem support, or Reading settings from baselayout
This project would allow arch teams to know how much testing each package gets and it would let developers know about what types of CFLAGS/USE flags our users are utilising

The Gentoo/*BSD project, while maturing quickly, still needs a lot of work in several areas. Useful project ideas include: catalyst support for building *BSD stages and livecds, porting Sandbox to work on BSD systems, better support for BSD file flags in Portage, Gnome porting (running GNOME on FreeBSD requires a large collection of patches from the Ports collection; this project would clean these up, make them more generic, and attempt to send them upstream so that others can benefit), and potentially modifying alsa-lib to use FreeBSD's OSS system as a sound backend, so that applications written to use ALSA can work unmodified on FreeBSD. Also useful would be to port Gentoo/FreeBSD to AMD64, and potentially other, hardware, sorting out any architecture issues that may crop up, such as building a proper multilib toolchain.

Provide an implementation of GLEP 27 in which ebuilds may add and remove necessary accounts in a variety of environments. At present only /etc/passwd is support. Adding support for LDAP and NIS/NIS+ environments would increase the usefulness of the Portage system.
Scire project - Systems Configuration, Installation, and Replication Environment
Scire is a new project in Gentoo that aims to install, configure, and replicate gentoo installations onto numerous machines.
Write a kernel module that performs similar sandboxing that the current sandbox application does. The kernel level sandbox is harder to fool, compared to the userland sandbox that is currently used.

Create an application that takes a stock portage tree and molds it to fit certain needs. For example, the application could remove Xorg and all ebuilds that depend on it. This would be like stripping packages from the tree. One could also envision a scenario where the program is given a set of packages and builds a tree with only those packages and their dependencies ( recursively ) in it.

Basically allow developers to comment on specific lines in a program. Implement so that the tracker also tracks line and function moves such that developers do not have to repost their comments. Security developers can then note potential problems in code and review them.
Gentoo/*BSD related projects, GLEP 27 implementation, "ambitious student proposals"
Security and Auditing related projects, Project to create customized portage tree, others.
Willing to work on most anything
Backup Mentor for Stephen Bennett (spb), Gentoo/*BSD related projects
Portage modifications, Pkgcore modifications, Repoman modifications, Collecting stats on Gentoo's usage
Portage related projects, Anything with regards to Python

body.p: As a student: If you want to work on any of the suggested projects, or have a project idea of your own, you should apply through the Google page -- see the Student FAQ for information. The team is happy to discuss any ideas you may have before you apply to Google; see below for how to find us.

As a developer: If you have an idea for a project, or would like to become a mentor or join the gentoo-soc team, please get in touch by emailing any member of the team, or find us in #gentoo-soc on Freenode.
